titleStmt.title: Distributed Adaptive Neural Control for Stochastic Nonlinear Multiagent Systems

affiliation.orgName: Shandong University of Science and Technology
Shandong University of Science and Technology

analytic.title: Distributed Adaptive Neural Control for Stochastic Nonlinear Multiagent Systems

biblStruct.note: received June 30, 2016; revised September 4, 2016; accepted October 28, 2016.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, a consensus tracking problem of nonlinear multiagent systems is investigated under a directed communication topology. All the followers are modeled by stochastic nonlinear systems in nonstrict feedback form, where nonlinearities and stochastic disturbance terms are totally unknown. Based on the structural characteristic of neural networks (in Lemma 4), a novel distributed adaptive neural control scheme is put forward. The raised control method not only effectively handles unknown nonlinearities in nonstrict feedback systems, but also copes with the interactions among agents and coupling terms. Based on the stochastic Lyapunov functional method, it is indicated that all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded in probability and all followers' outputs are convergent to a neighborhood of the output of leader. At last, the efficiency of the control method is testified by a numerical example.

multiagent systems with strict-feedback form. For linearly parameterized uncertain multiple systems in strict-feedback form, a distributed adaptive control protocol was constructed in [44]. Furthermore, by using the backstepping-based adaptive neural control approach, Yoo [45] and Wang et al. [46] investigated the distributed adaptive tracking issue of strict-feedback multiagent systems with unknown nonlinearities. However, the effect of random noise on the system is not taken into consideration in the aforementioned results.

As is known to all, stochastic noise is inevitable in practice and it is one of factors that affects performance. So far, the stochastic nonlinear multiagent systems have not been fully investigated due to the complexity in theoretical analysis. In [47], the distributed tracking problem of multiagent systems with stochastic nonlinear dynamics was considered. Built on the backstepping design framework and stochastic stability theory, a distributed integrator design scheme was presented. However, it is assumed that unknown nonlinearity and stochastic disturbances terms are bounded by known smooth functions. This limits the applicability and popularity of the proposed design method since nonlinear functions and stochastic disturbances terms are often totally unknown. In addition, the consensus result in [47] requires that the subsystems must be in strict-feedback form.

For reasons discussed above, this paper studies the distributed adaptive tracking problem of stochastic nonlinear multiagent systems with nonstrict-feedback form under a directed graph. As stated in [48]- [50], the nonstrict feedback form is more general than strict feedback form and the performance analysis is more difficult. The main obstacles in controlling such a multiagent system lie in the following. In mth step of traditional backstepping design for ith follower of multiagent system, the virtual controller υ i,m can only be a function of state vector x i = [x i,1 , x i,2 , . . . , x i,m ] T , which must not contain the state vector [x i,m+1 , x i,m+2 , . . . , x i,n i ] T and state variables of other followers. The backstepping-based adaptive control method does not directly work in such a multiagent system because the nonlinearities contain all the state variables. To deal with nonlinear nonstrict feedback systems, some adaptive neural or fuzzy control schemes were presented in [48]- [52]. However, these control methods are only qualified for SISO nonlinear systems without networked communications. They could not be easily extended to multiagent systems under a directed graph topology since there are interactions and coupling terms among agents. By introducing a property of neural networks (NNs) into the controller design process and employing an adaptive neural control method, this 2168-2267 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

difficulty is successfully solved. The main innovations of this essay are reflected in below. 1) Compared with the consensus results achieved for multiagent systems, all agents are modeled by stochastic nonlinear systems in nonstrict feedback form, which are more general than the ones in [1]- [13] and [44]- [47].

In addition, stochastic disturbances and nonlinear terms are completely unknown, the boundedness assumption for them in [47] can be removed, which is more popular in practical applications. 2) By introducing a property of NNs into the backstepping design, not only nonstrict feedback form is successfully solved, but also the interactions among agents and coupling terms are effectively coped with. Based on the presented characteristic of NNs, the restrictive conditions for the bounding functions of nonlinearities in [48]- [52] are removed. Therefore, the proposed scheme makes the backstepping-based adaptive neural control approach more adaptable and easier to implement.

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.p: Let G = (ℵ, ) be a directed graph, where ℵ = {ℵ 1 , . . . , ℵ ν } denotes a nonempty set of agents and =⊆ ℵ × ℵ represents a set of arcs. (ℵ j , ℵ i ) ∈ means that agent i can acquire information from agent j. The neighbors of agent i are expressed as
div.formula: N i = {ℵ j |(ℵ j , ℵ i ) ∈ }.
div.p: The topology of graph G is represented by a adjacency matrix A = [a ij ] ∈ R ν×ν with a ij ≥ 0. Define the graph Laplacian matrix as L = -A, where = diag(d 1 , . . . , d ν ) ∈ R ν×ν is the in-degree matrix with d i = ν j=1 a ij being the in-degree of agent i. In the directed graph G, a sequence of successive edges in the form {(ℵ i , ℵ k ), (ℵ k , ℵ l ), . . . , (ℵ m , ℵ j )} is said to a direct path from agent i to agent j. G is called to have a spanning tree, if there exists a directed path from the root to all other agents. G is called strongly connected, if there exists a directed path from agent i to agent j, for all distinct agents ℵ i , ℵ j ∈ ℵ.

div.head: B. Problem Formulation
div.p: Consider a set of ν(ν ≥ 2) followers with the following stochastic nonlinear dynamics:
div.formula: dx i,m = x i,m+1 + f i,m (x i ) dt + ψ i,m (x i )dw 1 ≤ m ≤ n i -1 dx i,n i = u i + f i,n i (x i ) dt + ψ i,n i (x i )dw y i = x i,1(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i = [x i,1 , x i,2 , . . . , x i,n i ] T ∈ R n i is the state vector of the ith follower, f i,m (x i ) and ψ i,m (x i ) (m = 1, 2, . . . , n i )
div.p: are unknown smooth functions, and u i and y i indicate input and output of the ith follower, respectively. w denotes an rdimension standard Brownian motion defined on the complete probability space ( , F, {F t } t≥0 , P) with being a sample space, F being a σ -field, {F t } t≥0 being a filtration, and P being a probability measure.

Remark 1: Different from the available consensus works, multiagent systems (1) are in nonstrict feedback form. In the multiagent systems (1), functions f i,m (•), ψ i,m (•) include the whole state vector x i , which is not reported in the existing consensus works. Such a multiagent model is more interesting and challenging.

Remark 2: Compared with the stochastic strict-feedback multiagent system in [47], f i,m (•), ψ i,m (•) are completely unknown, which are required to be bounded by known functions in [47]. However, in many practical multiagent systems, the bounded functions are often unknown, therefore the study for the stochastic multiagent systems with unknown nonlinearities makes more sense.
For the convenience of subsequent design, the following assumptions are required.
Assumption 1: The nth order time derivatives of leader output y r (t) is continuous, and it only can be obtained by the ith agents satisfying 0 ∈ N i , i = 1, . . . , ν.
Assumption 2:
1) The augmented graph Ḡ = ( ‫,א‬ ¯ ) with ‫א‬ = {ℵ 0 , ℵ 1 , . . . , ℵ ν } has a spanning tree, where the leader 0 denotes the root of Ḡ.

2) The state information of the ith follower is only obtained by the jth follower which satisfies i ∈ N j , i = 1, . . . , ν, m = 1, . . . , n i , j = 1, . . . , ν, and i = j. Remark 3: According to [11], the output of the ith agent y i (i = 1, 2, . . . , ν) synchronizes to the leader output y r if and only if Assumption 2 1) is satisfied, and Assumption 2 1)
div.formula: means b i + d i > 0.
div.p: Definition 1 [53]: V(x, t) is a twice continuously differentiable function, define its differential operator L of stochastic multiagent systems (1)
div.formula: LV = ∂V ∂t + ∂V ∂x f + 1 2 Tr ψ T ∂ 2 V ∂x 2 ψ (2)
div.p: where Tr signifies the matrix trace. Definition 2: The consensus tracking errors between the followers (1) and leader under the directed graph are called to be cooperatively semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded (CSUUB) in probability if for ∀ε > 0, E|y i (t)y r (t)| 4 ≤ ε when t → ∞, where E represents the expectation operator, i = 1, . . . , ν.
This paper aims to design u i for all followers such that all follower outputs y i are convergent to a neighborhood of the output of leader y r in probability.
Motivated by Zhang and Lewis [12] and Li and Zhang [47], define synchronization error as
div.formula: s i,1 = ν j=1 a ij y i -y j + b i (y i -y r ) (3)
div.p: where the pinning gains b i ≥ 0, b i > 0 only when the ith follower could obtain information from the leader 0.
The following lemmas have important roles in the stability analysis.
Lemma 1 [11]:
div.formula: Define = diag{b i } ∈ R ν×ν , if there exists b i > 0, then L + is nonsingular.
div.p: Lemma 2 [11]: Define s .1 = (s 1,1 , s 2,1 , . . . , s ν,1 ) T , y = (y 1 , y 2 , . . . , y ν ) T , y r = (y r , y r , . . . , y r ) T , then one has
where σ (L + ) is the minimum singular value of L + .
Lemma 3 [54]: If there are a function V(x, t) ∈ C 2,1 , two positive constants μ and τ , κ ∞ -functions β 1 and β 2 , such that
div.formula: β 1 ( x ) ≤ V(x, t) ≤ β 2 ( x ) LV ≤ -μV(x, t) + τ (5)
div.p: for ∀x ∈ R n and ∀t > 0. Then, there exists an unique strong solution of system (1) for ∀x 0 ∈ R n and all the signals of the controlled system are bounded in probability.

div.head: C. RBF Neural Networks
div.p: In the following design, the radial basis function (RBF) NNs will be utilized to approximate an unknown function f (ζ ) defined on some compact set . As shown in [50], for sufficiently large nodes number κ, the RBF NNs ξ * T (ζ ) can approximate any continuous function f (ζ ) over a compact set ⊂ R q to arbitrary accuracy ε > 0 as follows:
div.formula: f (ζ ) = ξ * T (ζ ) + (ζ ), ∀ζ ∈ ⊂ R q
div.p: where approximation error
div.formula: (ζ ) satisfies | (ζ ) |≤ ε, (ζ ) = [φ 1 (ζ ), φ 2 (ζ ), . . . , φ κ (ζ )] T is the basis function vector, ξ * = [ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ κ ] T ∈ R κ is ξ * := arg min ξ ∈R κ sup ζ ∈ f (ζ ) -ξ T (ζ )
div.p: where ξ ∈ R κ denotes the weight vector. In this paper, the following Gaussian basis function φ i (ζ ) will be utilized:
div.formula: φ i (ζ ) = exp - (ζ -ι i ) T (ζ -ι i ) ω 2 i , i = 1, 2, . . . , κ(6)
div.p: where ι i = [ι i1 , ι i2 , . . . , ι iq ] T represents the center of the receptive field and ω i is the width of the Gaussian function. Lemma 4: Let xq = [x 1 , . . . , x q ] T and (x q ) = [φ 1 (x q ), . . . , φ κ (x q )] T be the basis function vector of an RBF NN. Then, for any positive integer p ≤ q, one has
div.formula: xq 2 ≤ xp 2 .
div.p: Proof: For i = 1, . . . , κ, according to the definition ( 6), one has
div.formula: xq 2 = κ i=1 q t=1 exp - 1 ω 2 (x i -ι it ) 2 2 ≤ κ i=1 p t=1 exp - 1 ω 2 (x i -ι it ) 2 2 = xp 2 .
div.p: Remark 4: This lemma provides a simple but useful characteristic of RBF NN. As shown later, by which adaptive neural backstepping design method can be extended to the system (1) easily.

div.head: III. ADAPTIVE DISTRIBUTED CONTROLLERS DESIGN
div.p: In this section, an adaptive distributed design scheme will be developed based on backstepping technique. Before the design process, define ς i,m = ξ * i,m 2 , i = 1, 2, . . . , ν, m = 1, 2, . . . , n i , where ξ * i,m denotes the weight vector of neutral network and ς i,m represents an unknown positive constant. Let ςi,m be the estimate of ς i,m , then the estimated error can be expressed as ςi,m = ς i,m -ςi,m . In the following design, a change of coordinates is applied by:
div.formula: s i,m = x i,m -υ i,m-1 , m = 2, . . . , n i (7

Remark 5: Considering that fi,1 concludes the whole state variables x i and x j , the existing backstepping-based adaptive fuzzy/neural control methods in [46] and [47] for strictfeedback multiagent systems cannot applied to system (1). In the subsequent analysis, based on the structural characteristic of RBF NN (in Lemma 4), this difficulty is overcome, which makes the backstepping-based adaptive neural control approach more adaptable.
According to Young's inequality and Lemma 4, for a given a i,1 > 0, one has

Similarly, the RBF NN ξ * T i,m i,m (ζ i,m ) is employed to approximate the unknown function fi,m , that is, for ε i,m > 0, one has fi,m = ξ * T i,m i,m ζ i,m + i,m ζ i,m , i,m ζ i,m ≤ ε i,m .(28)

div.formula: μ i = min 2c i,m , γ i,m > 0, m = 1, 2, . . . , n i then one has LV i,n i ≤ -μ i V i,n i + τ i . (42
div.p: Based on the above discussion, the main result is stated as the following theorem.

Theorem 1: For the stochastic uncertain nonlinear followers in nonstrict feedback form (1) under Assumptions 1 and 2, if the distributed neural control protocols (39) and the parameter adaptive laws (32) are employed, all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded in probability. Furthermore, all followers' outputs are convergent to a neighborhood of the output of leader.
Proof: Consider the following total Lyapunov function V:
div.formula: V = ν i=1 V i,n i (t). (43
div.p: From ( 42), we have
div.formula: LV ≤ -μV + τ (44
div.p: where μ = min{μ i , i = 1, 2, . . . , ν}, τ = ν i=1 τ i . From the definition of V and Lemma 3, all the signals of the closed-loop system are CSUUB in probability. Furthermore, according to [55] and (44), one has
From ( 45), one obtains
div.formula: 0 ≤ E[V(t)] ≤ V(0) - τ μ e -μt + τ μ (46
div.p: which means that
For s .1 = (s 1,1 , s 2,1 , . . . , s ν,1 ) T , according to the definition of V and ( 47), one has
From the definitions of μ and τ , theoretically, for ∀ε > 0, by choosing the design parameters c i,m , γ i,m sufficiently large, choosing a i,m sufficiently small, one can obtains
Furthermore, according to Lemma 2, as t → ∞, the following inequality is satisfied:
By Definition 2, the tracking errors between the follower outputs y i and the leader output y r are CSUUB in probability.

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: Consider a five-followers digraph G and a leader as Fig. 1 shows. The followers are modeled by the following stochastic multiagent systems in nonstrict feedback form: The output of the leader is y r = sin 0.5t + 0.5 sin 1.5t. Remark 6: Obviously, the subsystem ( 51) is nonstrict feedback system, which is more generalized than the strictfeedback form. Theoretically, the existing control schemes are invalid for such a multiagent system.
div.formula: dx i,1 = x i,2 + 0.5x 2 i,1 x i,2 dt + 0.2 cos x 2 i,1 x i,2 dw dx i,2 = u i -0.5x i,2 dt -1.96x i,2 sin x i,1 dw y i = x i,1 .(51)
div.p: Choose the virtual controller υ i,1 (16), the parameter adaptive laws c Figs. 234567shows the simulation results, from which, it is shown that the developed controller can guarantee the desired consensus tracking performance.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper studies a distributed adaptive consensus issue for stochastic multiagent nonlinear systems under the directed topology graphic. To deal with the nonlinear functions of the followers's dynamic in nonstrict feedback form, the structural characteristic of NNs is first established. Then, combining the adaptive neural control method, compensation for the unknown nonlinearities and unknown stochastic disturbances is made.

Furthermore, the interactions among agents and coupling terms are effectively coped with. Based on the stochastic Lyapunov functional method, it is proved that all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded in probability and all followers' outputs are convergent to a neighborhood of the output of leader. Considering time delays issue in the network-based multiagent systems, the presented control approach is being promoted to stochastic multiagent systems with time-delay in our future studies.

div.p: This work was supported in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61473160 and Grant 61503223, in part by the Project of Shandong Province Higher Educational Science and Technology Program under Grant J15LI09, in part by the China Post-Doctoral Science Foundation under Project 2016M592140, and in part by the Shandong Innovation Post-Doctoral Program under Grant 201603066. This paper was recommended by Associate Editor W.

analytic.title: On consensus algorithms for double-integrator dynamics
Adaptive second-order consensus of networked mobile agents with nonlinear dynamics
Consensus control for a class of networks of dynamic agents
Rendezvous of multiple mobile agents with preserved network connectivity
